results.title: Fishtank
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
A high-rise flat in the U.K. Midlands. Ray is the father who drinks, Liz the mother, Jason the brother. There are some animals and the brother kills flies. The older brother films them with his handycam - intently observing whatever is going on.

In 1996 Richard Billingham’s ‘Ray’s a Laugh’ was hailed as the photo book of the decade. His photographs were one of the talking points of ‘Sensation’. Billingham has now made ‘Fishtank’, a commission for television by Artangel in collaboration with film-maker Adam Curtis and Illuminations TV for BBC2’s acclaimed TV series. The ‘video verite’ of Fishtank is contained within the compressed space/fishtank of the flat. Sometimes they talk, sometimes they argue. Billingham’s film registers the emotional temperature of this space and the family who live there with a closeness that transcends camera conventions. Like the paintings of Lucian Freud, Billingham crafts a terrible beauty from the landscape of family life and its patterns of pathos, despair and hope.

results.title: Fishtank
results.creator_credit: Denis Quinn, Marie-Louise Simpson, Queensland University of Technology and Super Fresh Oyster Films
results.brief_description: An adult reflects on a time in his youth when he used to wait for his father at the Regatta Hotel in Queensland during the sixties. It was a time when the muffled mutterings at the bar concerned issues such as women, pictures, and what it meant to be part of the “lucky country”. It was a men’s club, one legally and morally off limits to women, until 2 of them enter the bar, and, after being evicted handcuff themselves to the bar as a form of protest. Based on a true event and narrated by Daniel Rowan. Cast includes Dave Robinson, Damien Donowan, Stephen Collins, Liesel Badorrek and Kyrra Mickelborough.

results.title: Fishing the lake country
results.creator_credit: Ossie Emery, Betti Wood, Australian Broadcasting Commission and Pilgrim Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Fisherman’s World”.
Ron Calcutt shows some attractive fishing spots in Sydney and Mallacoota before going to the Gippsland Lakes. All through the film he gives hints on fishing, as well as discussing the ups and downs of the sport.

results.title: Fishing on the Diamantina
results.creator_credit: Wayne Gwynne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Wayne Gwynne joined the Navy in 1960 when he was 17. Spending 5 years at sea, during peacetime, Gwynne got to see things that no one has seen before. While he still can’t talk about those things, he loved his time at sea, especially on his favourite ship, the ‘Diamantina’.

results.title: Fishing on the coast of Japan
results.creator_credit: Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: Depicts the rigorous existence of Japanese fisherman. This film is non-narrated with Japanese music serving as the background. Shows the preparation of the nets, men and women pulling the boats into the sea, look outs for fish, the final catch, return home and the unloading. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Fishing across Canada
results.brief_description: Screen Magazine: Herring from the river: fishermen-farmers of the Gasperaux Valley in Nova Scotia catch herring upriver. Fish below the ice: Cree Indians of northern Manitoba fish in wintertime by stringing nets between holes in the ice. Home for young trout: to stock mountain lakes in the Canadian Rockies, fish are raised in hatcheries, the largest in Jasper National Park. Salmon on the run: on Canada’s west coast, commercial fishing vessels haul in huge catches. A glimpse of the of the multi-million-dollar salmon industry of Canada’s west coast.

results.title: Fishing
results.creator_credit: Frank L. Few and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Illustrates the fishing methods of the Australian Aborigine. They are shown fishing on a lake, using three-pronged spears from bark canoes. With Bill Onus.

results.title: Fishery in Japan
results.brief_description: Fish plays a large part in the diet of the Japanese people, providing them with much needed protein. It is eaten in various forms, some of which are a delight to the eye as well as the palate. Japan has one of the world’s largest and most efficient fishing industries, all types of fishing operations, coastal and deep-sea, canning and freezing operations are shown.
